00013 #include "GeographicLib/Geodesic.hpp"
00014 #include "GeographicLib/Constants.hpp"

00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief Cassini-Soldner Projection.
00020    *
00021    * Cassini-Soldner projection centered at an arbitrary position, \e lat0, \e
00022    * lon0, on the ellipsoid.  This projection is a transverse cylindrical
00023    * equidistant projection.  The projection from (\e lat, \e lon) to easting
00024    * and northing (\e x, \e y) is defined by geodesics as follows.  Go north
00025    * along a geodesic a distance \e y from the central point; then turn
00026    * clockwise 90<sup>o</sup> and go a distance \e x along a geodesic.
00027    * (Although the initial heading is north, this changes to south if the pole
00028    * is crossed.)  This procedure uniquely defines the reverse projection.  The
00029    * forward projection is constructed as follows.  Find the point (\e lat1, \e
00030    * lon1) on the meridian closest to (\e lat, \e lon).  Here we consider the
00031    * full meridian so that \e lon1 may be either \e lon0 or \e lon0 +
00032    * 180<sup>o</sup>.  \e x is the geodesic distance from (\e lat1, \e lon1) to
00033    * (\e lat, \e lon), appropriately signed according to which side of the
00034    * central meridian (\e lat, \e lon) lies.  \e y is the shortest distance
00035    * along the meridian from (\e lat0, \e lon0) to (\e lat1, \e lon1), again,
00036    * appropriately signed according to the initial heading.  [Note that, in the
00037    * case of prolate ellipsoids, the shortest meridional path from (\e lat0, \e
00038    * lon0) to (\e lat1, \e lon1) may not be the shortest path.]  This procedure
00039    * uniquely defines the forward projection except for a small class of points
00040    * for which there may be two equally short routes for either leg of the
00041    * path.
00042    *
00043    * Because of the properties of geodesics, the (\e x, \e y) grid is
00044    * orthogonal.  The scale in the easting direction is unity.  The scale, \e
00045    * k, in the northing direction is unity on the central meridian and
00046    * increases away from the central meridian.  The projection routines return
00047    * \e azi, the true bearing of the easting direction, and \e rk = 1/\e k, the
00048    * reciprocal of the scale in the northing direction.
00049    *
00050    * The conversions all take place using a GeographicLib::Geodesic object (by
00051    * default GeographicLib::Geodesic::WGS84).  For more information on
00052    * geodesics see \ref geodesic.  The determination of (\e lat1, \e lon1) in
00053    * the forward projection is by solving the inverse geodesic problem for (\e
00054    * lat, \e lon) and its twin obtained by reflection in the meridional plane.
00055    * The scale is found by determining where two neighboring geodesics
00056    * intersecting the central meridan at \e lat1 and \e lat1 + \e dlat1
00057    * intersect and taking the ratio of the reduced lengths for the two
00058    * geodesics between that point and, respectively, (\e lat1, \e lon1) and (\e
00059    * lat, \e lon).
00060    **********************************************************************/
00061 
00062   class CassiniSoldner {
00063   private:
00064     typedef Math::real real;
00065     const Geodesic _earth;
00066     GeodesicLine _meridian;
00067     real _sbet0, _cbet0;
00068     real Scale(const GeodesicLine& perp, real sig12) const throw();
00069     static const real eps1, eps2;
00070     static const unsigned maxit =  10;
00071 
00072     static inline real sq(real x) throw() { return x * x; }
00073   public:
00074 
00075     /**
00076      * Constructor for CassiniSoldner setting the Geodesic object, \e earth, to
00077      * use for geodesic calculations.  By default this uses the WGS84
00078      * ellipsoid.  This constructor makes an "uninitialized" object.  Call
00079      * Reset to set the central latitude and longuitude, prior to calling
00080      * Forward and Reverse.
00081      **********************************************************************/
00082     explicit CassiniSoldner(const Geodesic& earth = Geodesic::WGS84) throw()
00083       : _earth(earth) {}
00084 
00085     /**
00086      * Constructor for CassiniSoldner setting the center point, \e lat0, \e
00087      * lon0 (degrees) of the projection and the Geodesic object, \e earth, to
00088      * use for geodesic calculations.  By default this uses the WGS84
00089      * ellipsoid.
00090      **********************************************************************/
00091     CassiniSoldner(real lat0, real lon0,
00092                    const Geodesic& earth = Geodesic::WGS84) throw()
00093       : _earth(earth) {
00094       Reset(lat0, lon0);
00095     }
00096 
00097     /**
00098      * Set the central latititude to \e lat0 and central longitude to \e lon0
00099      * (degrees).  \e lat0 should be in the range [-90, 90] and \e lon0 should
00100      * be in the range [-180, 360].
00101      **********************************************************************/
00102     void Reset(real lat0, real lon0) throw();
00103 
00104     /**
00105      * Convert from latitude \e lat (degrees) and longitude \e lon (degrees) to
00106      * Cassini-Soldner easting \e x (meters) and northing \e y (meters).  Also
00107      * return the azimuth of the easting direction \e azi (degrees) and the
00108      * reciprocal of the northing scale \e rk.  \e lat should be in the range
00109      * [-90, 90] and \e lon should be in the range [-180, 360].  A call to
00110      * Forward followed by a call to Reverse will return the original (\e lat,
00111      * \e lon) (to within roundoff).  The routine does nothing if the origin
00112      * has not been set.
00113      **********************************************************************/
00114     void Forward(real lat, real lon,
00115                  real& x, real& y, real& azi, real& rk) const throw();
00116 
00117     /**
00118      * Convert from Cassini-Soldner easting \e x (meters) and northing \e y
00119      * (meters) to latitude \e lat (degrees) and longitude \e lon (degrees).
00120      * Also return the azimuth of the easting direction \e azi (degrees) and
00121      * the reciprocal of the northing scale \e rk.  A call to Reverse followed
00122      * by a call to Forward will return the original (\e x, \e y) (to within
00123      * roundoff), provided that \e x and \e y are sufficiently small not to
00124      * "wrap around" the earth.  The routine does nothing if the origin has not
00125      * been set.
00126      **********************************************************************/
00127     void Reverse(real x, real y,
00128                  real& lat, real& lon, real& azi, real& rk) const throw();
00129 
00130     /**
00131      * Has this object been initialized with an origin?
00132      **********************************************************************/
00133     bool Init() const throw() { return _meridian.Init(); }
00134 
00135     /**
00136      * Return the latitude of the origin (degrees).
00137      **********************************************************************/
00138     Math::real LatitudeOrigin() const throw()
00139     { return _meridian.Latitude(); }
00140 
00141     /**
00142      * Return the longitude of the origin (degrees).
00143      **********************************************************************/
00144     Math::real LongitudeOrigin() const throw()
00145     { return _meridian.Longitude(); }
00146 
00147     /**
00148      * The major radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is that value of \e a
00149      * inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.
00150      **********************************************************************/
00151     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _earth.MajorRadius(); }
00152 
00153     /**
00154      * The inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is that value of \e r
00155      * inherited from the Geodesic object used in the constructor.  A value of
00156      * 0 is returned for a sphere (infinite inverse flattening).
00157      **********************************************************************/
00158     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw()
00159     { return _earth.InverseFlattening(); }
00160   };
00161 
00162 } // namespace GeographicLib
